I had heard that the book this movie is based on was excellent, so I bought it and read it before the movie came out so that I could compare the two. Even though the book is not one of the greatest novels ever written, it was still pretty good and I finished reading it in two days. So needless to say, I was excited about the movie.

Well, after seeing the movie, I wish I hadn't read the book first; that way I wouldn't have been as disappointed as I was. The makers of the movie strayed very far from the novel. The novel created a good back story to the main character Zoe, and gave a deeper look into the book's antagonist, Quentin. Basically, the story is about Zoe's addiction to sex and how it has started to ruin her life. She is sleeping with three men: her husband, her client (Quentin), and another man she met at a club, Corey. Her addiction has become dangerous and it may even cost her her life.

The novel had suspense, humor, very good erotic undertones, and a good sense of character development. The movie however decided to do away with all of that and just show a lot of sex scenes. It basically just seemed like a soap opera. The movie didn't even get into the real reason why Zoe was addicted to sex, and why her and her husband had problems in the bedroom. It just left so much to be desired.

The acting was okay, but that was because they weren't really given any good material to work with. And the three lead males are great eye candy for women, but that is not enough to carry this movie to a good performance.

So if you are expecting this to be just as good as the novel, maybe you should just stay away completely unless you don't mind being highly disappointed. The makers of the movie really let down the readers. I hope someone else remakes this and actually stays true to the novel this time.

Have you ever been addicted to something you felt ashamed about?  Well if you're Sharon Leal's character, that addiction is sex!  Addicted had the potential to be a great movie, but as it is it's just an average one... maybe even below average.  Unfortunately the movie relies on a dramatic far-fetched take on a sexual addiction instead of a realistic one (and as you may or may not know, real sex addictions *do* exist).  The movie could have been a great opportunity to show a realistic portrayal of a sex addiction but instead t  relies on a story and atmosphere more comparable to a soap opera.

When Sharon's husband (Boris Kodjoe) refuses to satisfy the appetite-hungry woman on numerous times in a single bed sitting, she has to rely on uh, the internet and uh, toys.  Yup, no need to be specific here!  Clearly she craves sex a lot more than the average person!  A husband's dream, haha.  I kid.  Then again perhaps many people have the same high level of sex craving but know how to keep it under control.  Poor Sharon doesn't possess self-restraint.

Anyway when she finds herself at an art museum and meeting up with William Levy's character.  He comes off like a sophisticated ladies man capable of turning on tremendous charm!  She of course falls for it.  Later on the movie plays on the possibility that William might have a dangerous side when Sharon visits his place and a mysterious super attractive girl is there, but unfortunately for viewers the story never touches on that aspect until the end.  Instead we see a *very* bland and exaggerated ladies man character for the most part.  I almost want to say Sharon's husband is a more interesting character than William.

Throughout the movie Sharon tries hiding her sexual addiction, and it's almost hilarious when it appears her workmates find out she's been cheating on her husband and stare at her when she enters the building, so she feels shame about it and wears sunglasses to hide her identity.  It comes off *really* fake.  It's all in her head though- they know nothing!  Another thing that's mysterious about this movie is that Sharon's apparently been seeing yet another man, Tyson Beckford's character, but he doesn't play *nearly* as big of a role as William or Boris so his character feels tacked on.

I don't know, this movie felt like it should have been something more.  Sharon constantly lies to her kids and comes up with excuses why she couldn't attend their soccer games all because she's been seeing this other man, and her mother who lives with the family always senses Sharon's behavior is off but never questions it.  It takes until Sharon comes home late at night for the husband to wait up and question where she goes.  Sharon doesn't even give a proper answer and instead makes excuses, which should be *very* obvious to any husband that his wife is out there cheating.  Also interesting is that William is actually the one who initially hits on Sharon, not the other way around.  We can chalk this up to poor character use.

The one bright spot is the final 20 minutes.  A series of unfortunate events occur thanks to Sharon's lies and cheating finally catching up to her, and it's all rather surprising.  This is when the husband's character shines and we see his reactions.  Certainly that one violent outburst near the end was really awful writing I'm afraid.  A missed opportunity for something more intense.  But then again it was needed to lead into the next part (that I won't mention!)  Also the many visits Sharon has with her psychiatrist is pretty good writing, though the feeling is that Sharon isn't listening to a single word the lady is saying.  I guess that's an accurate portrayal of an addiction though.

So yeah, if it wasn't for the surprising stuff going on at the end I'd say this movie is a predictable exaggerated dud.  Otherwise meh, I can't say Addicted is good enough to recommend.  The acting is good enough, but the predictable story and characters is too much to take.  However I will say I LOVE the song that plays during the credits.  I found out it's called "The Conqueror" by Estelle.  Very uplifting message and melody, and a great music video that you simply must check out.  Very fitting to end the movie with this song.

2) Baggage of individual spouses are still a part of the weight that a family will carry, and one past can be painful for both.

3) Affairs usually result from unresolved issues within a relationship. Marriages that wish to survive must find ways to push past these issues, rather through individual or collective problem-solving.

4) Love, understanding, patience, and forgiveness can get most people through nearly anything.

I recommend this movie for anyone who thinks they might be interested based upon the plot. If you're interested based upon the book, then you might want to read another review before watching.
